lines.value: victory gardens is morris county's smallest municipality measured both by size and population and its most densely populated
lines.name: English

lines.value: the origins of the borough began in 1941 when the federal government acquired in randolph township as the site of a 300-unit housing project for war industry employees
lines.name: English

lines.value: the borough's name is derived from the victory gardens planted at homes and parks during world war ii to provide additional supplies of fruits and vegetables
lines.name: English

lines.value: the federal government paid for all infrastructure
lines.name: English

lines.value: streets are named for us presidents
lines.name: English

lines.value: randolph township residents approved a referendum as part of a september 1951 special election in which voters were asked if the township's victory gardens neighborhood should be removed from the township and created as an independent municipality for its 1300 residents covering 92 acre
lines.name: English

lines.value: residents of other areas of randolph township argued that the compensation paid by the federal government for the more than 250 students attending the randolph township schools did not adequately cover the cost of their public education that the housing and other structures in victory gardens was out of compliance with the township's building and zoning ordinances and that the overwhelming democratic party political leanings of residents of victory gardens were out of sync with the largely republican party township
lines.name: English

lines.value: victory gardens was incorporated as a borough by an act of the new jersey legislature on june 20 1951 from portions of randolph township based on the results of the referendum passed on september 18 1951
lines.name: English

lines.value: a project approved in 1973 brought the construction of 184 units of garden apartments on a site covering providing additional rateables and offering permanent housing for an estimated 400 people that would contrast with the temporary original structures built in the 1940s that had long passed their expected lifespan

lines.value: victory gardens is governed under the borough form of new jersey municipal government
lines.name: English

lines.value: the governing body consists of a mayor and a borough council comprising six council members with all positions elected at large on a partisan basis as part of the november general election
lines.name: English

lines.value: a mayor is elected directly by the voters to a four year term of office
lines.name: English

lines.value: the borough council consists of six members elected to serve three year terms on a staggered basis with two seats coming up for election each year in a three year cycle
lines.name: English

lines.value: the borough form of government used by victory gardens the most common system used in the state is a weak mayor strong council government in which council members act as the legislative body with the mayor presiding at meetings and voting only in the event of a tie
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mayor can veto ordinances subject to an override by a two thirds majority vote of the council
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mayor makes committee and liaison assignments for council members and most appointments are made by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council
lines.name: English

lines.value: , the mayor of victory gardens is democrat david l holeman jr whose term of office ends december 31 2016
lines.name: English

lines.value: members of the borough council are vera cheatham d 2016 ondria garcia montes d 2018 james r glass d 2016 elected to serve an unexpired term veronica hedgepath d 2018 wayne jacobus d 2017 and ismael lorenzo sr d 2017
lines.name: English

lines.value: joan cegelka won election in november 2013 to serve the balance of the term expiring in 2014 that had been held by david holeman before he took office as mayor with vera cheatham winning reelection to a full three year term and independent hector lorenzo jr knocking off incumbent sonia hall for terms starting january 1 2014

lines.value: alfred deakin 3 august 18567 october 1919 was an australian politician who served as the second prime minister of australia in office for three separate terms - 1903 to 1904 1905 to 1908 and 1909 to 1910
lines.name: English

lines.value: before entering office he was a leader of the movement for australian federation
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin was born in melbourne and attended the university of melbourne before training as a barrister
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was elected to the victorian legislative assembly in 1879 aged 22 and became a government minister in 1883
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin was a major contributor to the establishment of liberal reforms in the colony including pro worker industrial reforms
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also played a major part in developing irrigation in australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: throughout the 1890s deakin was a participant in conferences of representatives of the australian colonies that were established to draft a constitution for the proposed federation
lines.name: English

lines.value: he played an important role in ensuring that the draft was liberal and democratic and in achieving compromises to enable its eventual success
lines.name: English

lines.value: between conferences he worked to popularise the concept of federation and campaigned for its acceptance in colonial referenda
lines.name: English

lines.value: he then fought hard to ensure acceptance of the proposed constitution by the government of the united kingdom
lines.name: English

lines.value: after federation deakin was attorney general in the barton government from 1901 to 1903
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was one of the chief architects of the white australia policy overseeing the drafting of the immigration restriction act 1901
lines.name: English

lines.value: as prime minister deakin completed a significant legislative program that makes him with labor's andrew fisher the founder of an effective commonwealth government
lines.name: English

lines.value: he expanded the high court provided major funding for the purchase of ships leading to the establishment of the royal australian navy as a significant force under the fisher government and established australian control of papua
lines.name: English

lines.value: confronted by the rising australian labor party in 1909 he merged his protectionist party with joseph cook's anti socialist party to create the commonwealth liberal party known commonly as the fusion the main ancestor of the modern liberal party of australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: the deakin led liberal party government lost to fisher labor at the 1910 election which saw the first time a federal political party had been elected with a majority in either house in federal parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin resigned from parliament prior to the 1913 election with joseph cook winning the liberal party leadership ballot
lines.name: English

lines.value: alfred was born on 3 august 1856
lines.name: English

lines.value: alfred deakin was the second child of english immigrants william deakin and his wife sarah bill daughter of a shropshire farmer who had migrated to australia in 1850 and settled in the melbourne suburb of collingwood in 1853
lines.name: English

lines.value: his father worked as a storekeeper water carter and general carrier and then became a partner in a coaching business and later manager of cobb and co in victoria
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin was born at 90 george street fitzroy melbourne and began his education at the age of four in a boarding school that was initially located at kyneton but later moved to the melbourne suburb of south yarra
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1864 he became a day pupil at melbourne church of england grammar school but did not study seriously until his later school years when he came under the influence of j h thompson and the school's headmaster john edward bromby whose oratorical style deakin admired and later partly adopted
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1871 he graduated with good passes in history algebra and euclid and basic passes in english and latin
lines.name: English

lines.value: he began evening classes in law at the university of melbourne while working as a schoolteacher and private tutor
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also spoke frequently at the university debating club founded by charles henry pearson in 1874 read widely dabbled in writing and became a lifelong spiritualist holding the office of president of the victorian spiritualists union
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin graduated in 1877 and began practising as a barrister but had difficulty in obtaining briefs
lines.name: English

lines.value: in may 1878 he met david syme the owner of the melbourne daily the age who paid him to contribute reviews leaders and articles on politics and literature
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1880 he became editor of the leader the age's weekly
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this period syme converted him from supporting free trade to protectionism
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became active in the australian natives association and began to practise vegetarianism
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin stood for the largely rural seat of west bourke in the victorian legislative assembly in february 1879 as a supporter of legislative council reform protection to encourage manufacturing and the introduction of a land tax to break up the big agricultural estates and won by 79 votes
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to a number of voters being disenfranchised by a shortage of voting papers he used his maiden speech to announce his resignation he lost the subsequent by election by 15 votes narrowly lost the seat in the february 1880 general election but won it in yet another early general election in july 1880
lines.name: English

lines.value: the radical premier graham berry offered him the position of attorney general in august but deakin turned him down
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1882 deakin married elizabeth martha anne pattie browne daughter of a well known spiritualist
lines.name: English

lines.value: they lived with deakin's parents until 1887 when they moved to llanarth in walsh street south yarra
lines.name: English

lines.value: they had three daughters ivy stella and vera by 1891
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1883 deakin became commissioner for public works and water supply and in 1884 he became solicitor general and minister of public works
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1885 deakin secured the passage of the colony's pioneering factories and shops act enforcing regulation of employment conditions and hours of work
lines.name: English

lines.value: in december 1884 he went to the united states to investigate irrigation and presented a report in june 1885 irrigation in western america
lines.name: English

lines.value: percival serle described this report as a remarkable piece of accurate observation and was immediately reprinted by the united states government
lines.name: English

lines.value: in june 1886 he introduced legislation to nationalise water rights and provide state aid for irrigation works that helped establish irrigation in australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1885 deakin became chief secretary and commissioner for water supply and from 1890 minister for health and briefly solicitor general
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1887 he led victoria's delegation to the imperial conference in london where he argued forcibly for reduced colonial payments for the defence provided by the british navy and for improved consultation in relation to the new hebrides
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1889 he became the member for the melbourne seat of essendon and flemington
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1890 the government was brought down over its use of the militia to protect non union labour during the maritime strike
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition deakin lost his fortune and his father's fortune in the property crash of 1893 and had to return to the bar to restore his finances
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1892 he unsuccessfully defended the mass murderer frederick bailey deeming and assisted the defence in the 1893 94 libel trial of david syme
lines.name: English

lines.value: after 1890 deakin refused all offers of cabinet posts and devoted his attention to the movement for federation
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was victoria's delegate to the australasian federal conference convened by sir henry parkes in melbourne in 1890 which agreed to hold an intercolonial convention to draft a federal constitution
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was a leading negotiator at the federal conventions of 1891 which produced a draft constitution that contained much of the constitution of australia as finally enacted in 1900
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin was also a delegate to the second australasian federal convention which opened in adelaide in march 1897 and concluded in melbourne in january 1898
lines.name: English

lines.value: he opposed conservative plans for the indirect election of senators attempted to weaken the powers of the senate in particular seeking to prevent it from being able to defeat money bills and supported wide taxation powers for the federal government
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin often had to reconcile differences and find ways out of apparently impossible difficulties
lines.name: English

lines.value: between and after these meetings he travelled through the country addressing public meetings and he was partly responsible for the large majority in victoria at each referendum
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1900 deakin travelled to london with edmund barton and charles kingston to oversee the passage of the federation bill through the imperial parliament and took part in the negotiations with joseph chamberlain the colonial secretary who insisted on the right of appeal from the high court to the privy council
lines.name: English

lines.value: eventually a compromise was reached under which constitutional inter se matters could be finalised in the high court but other matters could be appealed to the privy council
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin defined himself as an independent australian briton favouring a self governing australia but loyal to the british empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: he certainly did not see federation as marking australia's independence from britain
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the contrary deakin was a supporter of closer empire unity serving as president of the victorian branch of the imperial federation league a cause he believed to be a stepping stone to a more spiritual world unity
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1901 deakin was elected to the first federal parliament as mp for ballaarat and became attorney general in the ministry headed by edmund barton
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was active especially in drafting bills for the public service arbitration and the high court
lines.name: English

lines.value: his second reading speech on the immigration restriction bill to implement the white australia policy was notable for it's blatant racism including arguing that it was necessary to exclude the japanese because of their good qualities which would place them at an advantage over european australians
lines.name: English

lines.value: his march 1902 speech in favour of the bill establishing the high court of australia helped overcome significant opposition to its establishment
lines.name: English

lines.value: when barton retired to become one of the founding justices of the high court deakin succeeded him as prime minister on 24 september 1903
lines.name: English

lines.value: his protectionist party did not have a majority in either house and he held office only by courtesy of the labor party which insisted on legislation more radical than deakin was willing to accept
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin was the first pm to call an early election within two months of becoming the leader to catch his opponents off guard and take advantage of a large number of urban educated female voters who could cast a ballot for the first time
lines.name: English

lines.value: in april 1904 he resigned without passing any legislation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the labor leader chris watson and the free trade leader george reid succeeded him but neither could form a stable ministry
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin resumed office in mid 1905 and retained it for three years
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this the longest and most successful of his terms as prime minister his government was responsible for much policy and legislation giving shape to the commonwealth during its first decade including bills to create an australian currency
lines.name: English

lines.value: the copyright act was passed in 1905 the bureau of census and statistics was established in 1906 bureau of meteorology was established in 1908 and the quarantine act was passed in 1908
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1906 deakin's government amended the judiciary act to increase the size of the high court to five judges as envisaged in the constitution and appointed isaac isaacs and h b higgins to fill the two additional seats
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first protective federal tariff the australian industries protection act was passed
lines.name: English

lines.value: this new protection measure attempted to force companies to pay fair wages by setting conditions for tariff protection although the commonwealth had no powers over wages and prices
lines.name: English

lines.value: the papua act of 1905 established an australian administration for the former british new guinea and deakin appointed hubert murray as lieutenant governor of papua in 1908 who ruled it for a 32-year period as a benevolent paternalist
lines.name: English

lines.value: his government passed a bill for the transfer of control of the northern territory from south australia to the commonwealth which became effective in 1911
lines.name: English

lines.value: in december 1907 he introduced the first bill to establish compulsory military service which was also strongly supported by labor's watson and billy hughes
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had long opposed the naval agreements to fund royal navy protection of australia although barton had agreed in 1902 that the commonwealth would take over such funding from the colonies
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1906 he announced that australia would purchase destroyers and in 1907 travelled to an imperial conference in london to discuss the issue without success
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1908 he invited theodore roosevelt's great white fleet to visit australia in a symbolic act of independence from britain
lines.name: English

lines.value: the surplus revenue act of 1908 provided £250000 for naval expenditure although these funds were first applied by the andrew fisher labor government creating the first independent navy in the british empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1908 deakin was again forced from office by labor
lines.name: English

lines.value: he then formed a coalition the fusion with his old conservative opponent george reid and returned to power in may 1909 at the head of australia's first majority government
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fusion was seen by many as a betrayal of deakin's liberal principles and he was called a judas by sir william lyne
lines.name: English

lines.value: he ordered the dreadnought battle cruiser australia and established the financial agreement of 1909 which gave the states annual grants of 25 shillings $2.50 per person which was the basis of commonwealth state financial arrangements until 1927
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the april 1910 election his party was soundly defeated by labor under andrew fisher
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin retired from parliament in april 1913
lines.name: English

lines.value: he chaired the 1914 royal commission on food supplies and on trade and industry
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was president of the australian commission for the panama pacific international exposition held in san francisco in 1915 to celebrate the opening of the panama canal but found his duties difficult because of severe progressive memory loss due to dementia
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was the only australian prime minister to reject the title of right honourable
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became an invalid and died in 1919 of meningoencephalitis at age 63
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is buried in the st kilda cemetery alongside his wife pattie deakin b.1863 m.1882 d.1934
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his youth deakin published quentin massys a drama in five acts
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin attempted to burn the prints fortunately some survived and the play was reprinted 1940 as an example of australian verse deakin continued to write prolifically throughout his career
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was a member of the eclectic association fellow members included authors theodore fink arthur topp arthur patchett martin and david mickle
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin wrote anonymous political commentaries for the london morning post even while he was prime minister
lines.name: English

lines.value: his account of the federation movement appeared as the federal story in 1944 and is a vital primary source for this history
lines.name: English

lines.value: his account of his career in victorian politics in the 1880s was published as the crisis in victorian politics in 1957
lines.name: English

lines.value: his collected journalism was published as federated australia in 1968
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was active in the theosophical society until 1896 when he resigned on joining the australian church led by charles strong
lines.name: English

lines.value: though deakin always took pains to obscure the spiritual dimensions of his character from public gaze he felt a strong sense of providence and destiny working in his career
lines.name: English

lines.value: like dag hammarskjold much later deakin's sincere longing for spiritual fulfillment led him to express a sense of unworthiness in his private diaries which mingled with his literary aspirations as a poet
lines.name: English

lines.value: his private prayer diaries like those of samuel johnson express a profound contemplative though more ecumenical christian view of the importance of humility in seeking divine assistance with his career
lines.name: English

lines.value: a life the life of christ deakin wrote that is the one thing needful the only revelation required is there we have but to live it in 1888 as an example relevant to his work for federation deakin prayed oh god grant me that judgment & forsight which will enable me to serve my country guide me and strengthen me so that i may follow & persuade others to follow the path which shall lead to the elevation of national life & thought & permanence of well earned prosperity give me light & truth & influence for the highest & the highest only as walter murdoch pointed out [deakin] believed himself to be inspired and to have a divine message and mission historian manning clark whose history of australia cites extensively from his studies of deakin's private diaries in the national library of australia wrote by reading the world's scriptures and mystics a deep peace had settled far inside [deakin] now he felt a serenity at the core of my heart he wanted to know whether participation in the world's affairs would disturb that serenity he was tormented by the thought that the emptiness of the man within corresponded with the emptiness of society at large where mammon had found a new demesne to infest
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin was almost universally liked admired and respected by his contemporaries who called him affable alfred he made his only real enemies at the time of the fusion when not only labor but also some liberals such as sir william lyne reviled him as a traitor
lines.name: English

lines.value: deakin had a long and happy marriage and was survived by his wife and their three daughters in 1969 australia post honoured him on a postage stamp bearing his portrait
lines.name: English

lines.value: leftfield are a british electronic music group formed in 1989
lines.name: English

lines.value: it began as the duo of neil barnes and paul daley formerly of the rivals a man called adam and the brand new heavies
lines.name: English

lines.value: in january 2010 barnes resurrected leftfield without daley and after touring for a few years finished writing new material for a third album entitled alternative light source
lines.name: English

lines.value: daley declined to be involved and is focusing upon his solo career
lines.name: English

lines.value: the duo were very influential in the evolution of electronic music in the 1990s with mixmag describing them as the single most influential production team working in british dance music
lines.name: English

lines.value: as with many of their contemporaries such as the chemical brothers leftfield were notable for their use of guest vocalists in their works
lines.name: English

lines.value: among those involved were toni halliday on original johnny rotten on open up djum djum on afro left and earl 16 and cheshire cat on release the pressure
lines.name: English

lines.value: the term progressive house was coined to define their style a fusion of house with dub and reggae
lines.name: English

lines.value: neil barnes music career started off as a dj at the wag club while simultaneously playing percussion on a session basis
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1986 he joined the london school of samba and played in the bateria in the 1986 notting hill carnival
lines.name: English

lines.value: around 1989 inspired by afrika bambaataa barnes decided to try his hand at electronic music production the results of which were the tracks not forgotten and more than i know released on the rhythm king label
lines.name: English

lines.value: for the remixes of these tracks barnes called upon paul daley percussion player with a man called adam and formerly a session musician for the brand new heavies and primal scream appearing on their dixie narco ep
lines.name: English

lines.value: barnes and daley had previously worked together as percussionists at the sandals first club violets
lines.name: English

lines.value: described by barnes as [t]he sound of 15 years of frustration coming out in one record the piece was termed progressive house by mixmag and held significant prominence in nightclubs from 1991 onwards
lines.name: English

lines.value: as their mutual interest in electronic music became clear the pair decided that they would work instead upon leftfield once barnes had extricated himself from his now troublesome contract with rhythm king subsidiary outer rhythm
lines.name: English

lines.value: the name leftfield was originally used by barnes for his first single with editing arranging and additional production undertaken by daley
lines.name: English

lines.value: however after this daley was subsequently involved in remixing not forgotten and thereafter in the creation of all of leftfield's work until he left the band in 2002
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this period in which the band could not release their own music owing to the legal dispute with rhythm king the pair undertook remix work for react 2 rhythm icp supereal inner city sunscreem ultra nate and provided two remixes to david bowie's single jump they say
lines.name: English

lines.value: finally once the problems with their former label had been sorted out leftfield were able to unveil their single release the pressure
lines.name: English

lines.value: leftfield's first major career break came with the single open up a collaboration with john lydon of sex pistols fame that was soon followed by their debut album leftism in 1995 blending dub breakbeat and house
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was shortlisted for the 1995 mercury music prize but lost out to portishead's dummy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a 1998 q magazine poll readers voted it the eightieth greatest album of all time while in 2000 q placed it at number 34 in its list of the 100 greatest british albums ever
lines.name: English

lines.value: the album was rereleased in 2000 with a bonus disc of remixes and again in 2017 as a remastered version with eleven completely new remixes
lines.name: English

lines.value: their second album rhythm and stealth 1999 maintained a similar style and featured roots manuva afrika bambaataa and mc cheshire cat from birmingham
lines.name: English

lines.value: the album was shortlisted for the mercury music prize in 2000 but lost out to badly drawn boy's the hour of bewilderbeast

lines.value: it reached no
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1 in the uk albums chart

lines.value: jean georges noverre 29 april 1727 19 october 1810 was a french dancer and balletmaster and is generally considered the creator of ballet d'action a precursor of the narrative ballets of the 19th century

lines.value: his birthday is now observed as international dance day

lines.value: his first professional appearances occurred as a youth in paris at the opera-comique at fontainebleau in berlin before frederick ii and his brother prince henry of prussia in dresden and strasburg

lines.value: in 1747 he moved to strasbourg where he remained until 1750 before moving to lyon
lines.name: English

lines.value: the work was revived in paris in 1754 to great acclaim
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1755 he was invited by garrick to london where he remained for two years

lines.value: appearances in dresden and strasbourg followed before his return to the opera-comique
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1750 he became principal dancer in lyon and created his first ballet pantomime le jugement de parisin 1751

lines.value: noverre traveled to vienna where he worked under queen marie theresa and became maitre de danse for her twelve year old daughter marie antoinette

lines.value: louis de buade comte de frontenac et de palluau (; may 22 1622november 28 1698 was a french soldier courtier and governor general of new france from 1672 to 1682 and from 1689 to his death in 1698
lines.name: English

lines.value: he established a number of forts on the great lakes and engaged in a series of battles against the english and the iroquois
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his first term he supported the expansion of the fur trade establishing fort frontenac in what is now kingston ontario and came into conflict with the other members of the sovereign council over its expansion and over the corvees required to build the new forts

lines.value: the conflict with the sovereign council led to his recall in 1682

lines.value: his second term was characterised by the defence of quebec from a british invasion during king william's war a successful guerrilla campaign against the iroquois and english settlements which resulted in the elimination of the iroquois threat against new france and a large expansion of the fur trade using canadian coureurs des bois

lines.value: the de buades however were a family of distinction in the principality of bearn
lines.name: English

lines.value: antoine de buade seigneur de frontenac grandfather of the future governor of new france attained eminence as a councilor of state under henri iv and his children were brought up with the dauphin afterwards louis xiii
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac entered the army at an early age
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1635 he began his military career and he served under the prince of orange in holland and fought with credit and received many wounds during engagements in the low countries and in italy
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was promoted to the rank of colonel in the regiment of normandy in 1643 and three years later after distinguishing himself at the siege of orbetello where he had an arm broken he was made marechal de camp
lines.name: English

lines.value: seventeenth century warfare ceased during the winter months and frontenac being a soldier needed to keep occupied
lines.name: English

lines.value: like many military officers frontenac took residence at the king's court
lines.name: English

lines.value: unfortunately for frontenac such a lavish lifestyle proved to be costly and his time at the king's court only led him to amass more debt
lines.name: English

lines.value: his growing debt led him to seek an arret du conseil d etat later in his life in order to protect his properties from his creditors who otherwise would have been able to seize his properties
lines.name: English

lines.value: his service seems to have been continuous until the conclusion of the peace of westphalia in 1648 when he returned to his father's house in paris and married without the consent of her parents anne de la grange trianon in october 1648
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac courted her because she was set to inherit a large sum of money from her deceased mother and her father upon his death
lines.name: English

lines.value: anne de la grange trianon's father had remarried and had a second child to ensure that his fortune would not go to his daughter and the son in law that he disapproved of
lines.name: English

lines.value: therefore when frontenac's father in law died frontenac did not receive the money he was hoping for as his wife's father left his fortune to his new wife
lines.name: English

lines.value: the marriage was not a happy one and after the birth of a son incompatibility of temper led to a separation the count retiring to his estate on the indre where by an extravagant course of living he became hopelessly involved in debt
lines.name: English

lines.value: little is known of his career for the next fifteen years beyond the fact that he held a high position at court but in the year 1669 when france sent a contingent to assist the venetians in the defense of crete against the turks frontenac was placed in command of the troops on the recommendation of turenne
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this expedition he won military glory but his fortune was not improved thereby
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1664 frontenac admitted to owing debt of 325878 livres plus 17350 livres of interest to his creditors which was not repaid by 1672 when his property was seized by creditors
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac however was offered the position of governor general of new france which deferred his debts until the end of his governorship
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac was appointed governor and lieutenant general of new france acadia the island of newfoundland on april 7 1672 and arrived in quebec on the 7th of september that same year
lines.name: English

lines.value: a seventeenth century painting of anne de la grange trianon can be seen today at the chateau de versailles
lines.name: English

lines.value: at this period the affairs of new france claimed the unexpected attention of the french court
lines.name: English

lines.value: from the year 1665 the colony had been successfully administered by three men daniel de remy de courcelle the governor jean talon the intendant and the marquis de tracy who had been appointed lieutenant general for the french king in america but a difference of opinion had arisen between the governor and the intendant and each had demanded the others recall in the public interest
lines.name: English

lines.value: at this crisis in the administration of new france de frontenac was appointed to succeed de courcelle
lines.name: English

lines.value: from the beginning of frontenac's term it was evident that he was prepared to give effect to a policy of colonial expansion
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was also genuinely ambitious to inaugurate an era of prosperity for canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: he exercised an independence of action that did not coincide with the views of his minister colbert
lines.name: English

lines.value: as governor frontenac was undoubtedly the most powerful figure within the colony
lines.name: English

lines.value: among his most prominent duties as governor frontenac maintained control over military matters and foreign affairs
lines.name: English

lines.value: situated within the context of the french colony throughout the seventeenth century foreign affairs largely encompassed the relations between french settlers and indigenous peoples
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the governor was not allowed to intervene in matters handled by the sovereign council and the intendant persons in these formal posts had to respect the governor as the ultimate voice of authority
lines.name: English

lines.value: such compliance was based on the notion that the governor was the king's representative
lines.name: English

lines.value: the governor was not merely an intermediary or a stand in
lines.name: English

lines.value: the governor extended the king's authority from france to the north american colony
lines.name: English

lines.value: as one of his first acts as governor he established his presence as the sovereign delegate of the king by establishing in canada the three estates - nobles clergy and people - and convening a colonial estates general to pledge fealty to him
lines.name: English

lines.value: the arrival of the governor implied that all of the colony's settlers pledge their allegiance to the king
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was a duty that frontenac did not take lightly
lines.name: English

lines.value: the royal policy however was adverse to the granting of extensive political rights to the canadians and frontenac's reforms in this direction were disapproved
lines.name: English

lines.value: in relation to the hierarchy of authority within the colonial setting any check on the governor's power was altogether absent
lines.name: English

lines.value: in frontenac's case france's finance minister jean baptiste colbert who resided an ocean away could only impose restraints upon the governor's powers
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus measures were adopted to curb his ambition by increasing the power of the sovereign council and by reviving the office of intendant
lines.name: English

lines.value: responding to his reduction in the sovereign council to a figurehead he expressed his infuriation by challenging the authority of the intendant jacques duchesnau and demanding that the council refer to him as the chief and president
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac however was a man of dominant spirit jealous of authority prepared to exact obedience from all and to yield to none
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the course of events he soon became involved in quarrels with the intendant touching questions of precedence and with the ecclesiastics one or two of whom ventured to criticize his proceedings
lines.name: English

lines.value: the church in new france had been administered for many years by the religious orders for the see of quebec so long contemplated had not yet been erected
lines.name: English

lines.value: but three years after the arrival of frontenac a former vicar apostolic francois-xavier de montmorency laval returned to quebec as bishop with a jurisdiction over the whole of new france
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this redoubtable churchman the governor found a vigorous opponent who was determined to render the state subordinate to the church
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac following in this respect in the footsteps of his predecessors had issued trading licenses which permitted the sale of intoxicants
lines.name: English

lines.value: the bishop supported by the intendant endeavored to suppress this trade and sent an ambassador to france to obtain remedial action
lines.name: English

lines.value: the views of the bishop were upheld and henceforth authority was divided
lines.name: English

lines.value: troubles ensued between the governor and the sovereign council over its expansion and over the corvees required to build the new forts
lines.name: English

lines.value: in particular despite the opposition of bishop francois de laval he supported selling brandy to the first nations which laval considered a mortal sin
lines.name: English

lines.value: the king and his minister had to listen to and adjudicate upon the appeals from the contending parties until one incident wore their patience out
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the adolescent son of duchesneau was verbally abused on the street by a follower of frontenac frontenac physically assaulted him with his cane when he deemed his explanation unacceptable and after negotiation between himself the intendant and the bishop an officer of frontenac detained and imprisoned duchesneau's son
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the king's edict of 1679 it was forbidden for a governor to arbitrarily imprison any subjects
lines.name: English

lines.value: following a deliberation in versailles both governor and intendant were recalled to france in the year 1682
lines.name: English

lines.value: during frontenac's first administration many improvements had been made in the country
lines.name: English

lines.value: the defenses had been strengthened a fort was built at cataraqui now kingston ontario bearing the governor's name and conditions of peace had been fairly maintained between the iroquois on the one hand and the french and their allies the ottawas and the hurons on the other
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac made his way to cataraqui to build his post that would facilitate trading with the iroquois confederacy
lines.name: English

lines.value: even though frontenac was disobeying colbert's policies he was able to continuously act in such a way because he represented the king's person
lines.name: English

lines.value: throughout his first term frontenac was engaging in the fur trade to increase his own fortune and those of his associates
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to la salle in his personal memoir frontenac was also trying to secure a monopoly over a large part of the fur trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: the progress of events during the next few years proved that the recall of the governor had been ill timed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the iroquois were assuming a threatening attitude towards the inhabitants and frontenac's successor la barre was quite incapable of leading an army against such cunning foes
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the end of a year la barre was replaced by the marquis de denonville a man of ability and courage who though he showed some vigour in marching against the western iroquois tribes angered rather than intimidated them and the massacre of lachine on august 5 1689 must be regarded as one of the unhappy results of his administrations
lines.name: English

lines.value: the affairs of the colony were now in a critical condition a man of experience and decision was needed to cope with the difficulties and louis xiv who was not wanting in sagacity wisely made choice of the choleric count to represent and uphold the power of france
lines.name: English

lines.value: when therefore on october 17 1689 frontenac arrived in quebec as governor for the second time he received an enthusiastic welcome and confidence was at once restored in the public mind
lines.name: English

lines.value: quebec was not long to enjoy the blessing of peace
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac's return to new france during the nine years war offered him an opportunity to display his military capabilities against england in north america
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite the tensions created during his first term as governor general frontenac was still unwilling to share power with the sovereign council and continued to profit from the canadian fur trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: in january 1690 frontenac approved the use of raiding parties composed of canadians and indigenous allies to ravage english border settlements
lines.name: English

lines.value: these parties raided the towns of schenectady and salmon falls and indiscriminately murdered english settlers but spared the iroquois
lines.name: English

lines.value: the raids were intended to deter the english from forming an alliance with the iroquois but instead united the english colonies against new france
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 16 october 1690 several new england ships under the command of sir william phips governor of massachusetts appeared off the island of orleans and an officer was sent ashore to demand the surrender of the fort
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac bold and fearless responded with the famous words non je n'ai point de reponse a faire a votre general que par la bouche de mes canons et de mes fusils i have no reply to make to your general other than from the mouths of my cannons and muskets
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac handled so vigorously the forces he had collected as to completely repulse the enemy who in their hasty retreat left behind a few pieces of artillery on the beauport shore
lines.name: English

lines.value: the prestige of the governor was greatly increased by this event and he was prepared to follow up his advantage by an attack on boston from the sea but his resources were inadequate for the undertaking
lines.name: English

lines.value: new france now rejoiced in a brief respite from her enemies and during the interval frontenac encouraged the revival of the drama at the chateau st louis and paid some attention to the social life of the colony
lines.name: English

lines.value: new france had been under intermittent attack throughout the 17th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: the people however were not subdued and for two years after the phips attack a petty warfare was maintained
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sufferings of the colony infested by war parties were extreme
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fur trade which formed its only resource for subsistence was completely cut off and a great accumulation of furs remained in the trading posts of the upper lakes prevented from descending by the watchful enemy
lines.name: English

lines.value: to meet the threat he dispatched jean baptiste bissot sieur de vincennes to establish a trading post and fort at kekionga present day fort wayne indiana
lines.name: English

lines.value: at a grand council of the friendly tribes frontenac took up a hatchet brandished it in the air and sang the war song his officers following his example
lines.name: English

lines.value: the christian indians of the neighboring missions rose and joined them and so also did the hurons and the algonquins of lake nipissing while frontenac led the dance whooping like the rest
lines.name: English

lines.value: his allies roused to martial frenzy promised war to the death and several years of conflict followed
lines.name: English

lines.value: at length after three years of destitution and misery frontenac broke the blockade of the ottawa the coveted treasure came safely to montreal and the colonists hailed him as their father and deliverer
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1696 frontenac decided to take the field against the iroquois although at this time he was seventy six years of age
lines.name: English

lines.value: on july 6 he left lachine at the head of a considerable force for the village of the onondagas where he arrived a month later
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the meantime the iroquois had abandoned their villages and as pursuit was impracticable the army commenced its return march on august 10
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac endured the fatigue of the march as well as the youngest soldier and for his courage and prowess he received the cross of st louis
lines.name: English

lines.value: under frontenac's leadership the canadian militia became increasingly adept at guerrilla warfare and took the war into iroquois territory and attacked a number of english settlements
lines.name: English

lines.value: after waging a war of attrition between 1690 and 1698 the iroquois fled the raided territory and negotiated for peace with the french
lines.name: English

lines.value: the result was that the threat of the iroquois to new france was finally diffused
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time of his second appointment as governor in 1689 france authorized the importation of slaves to quebec from the west indies
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac died on november 28 1698 at the chateau st louis after a brief illness deeply mourned by the canadian people
lines.name: English

lines.value: the faults of the governor were those of temperament which had been fostered by early environment
lines.name: English

lines.value: his nature was turbulent and from his youth he had been used to command but underlying a rough and hard exterior there was evidence of a kindly heart
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was fearless resourceful and decisive and triumphed as few men could have done over the difficulties and dangers of a most critical position
lines.name: English

lines.value: quebec's most famous building and landmark the chateau frontenac is named after him as is the kingston frontenacs ice hockey team
lines.name: English

lines.value: in ontario frontenac provincial park near the site of the former fort frontenac and fort cataraqui present day kingston is also named in his honour
lines.name: English

lines.value: in quebec frontenac national park commemorates his governorship and leadership of canada during challenging period of war with the british colonies
lines.name: English

lines.value: many sites and landmarks were named to honor louis de buade de frontenac
lines.name: English

lines.value: they include
lines.name: English

lines.value: frontenac's coat of arms marks the entrance to the chateau part of which lies on the site of his former home
lines.name: English

lines.value: some have spotted him dressed in 17th century garb wandering the halls or floating through the ballroom
lines.name: English

lines.value: legacy code is source code that relates to a no longer supported or manufactured operating system or other computer technology
lines.name: English

lines.value: the term was first used by computer scientist george olivetti to describe code maintained by an administrator that did not develop the code
lines.name: English

lines.value: the term can also mean code inserted into modern software for the purpose of maintaining an older or previously supported feature for example supporting a serial interface even though many modern systems do not have a serial port
lines.name: English

lines.value: it may also be in the form of supporting older file formats that may have been encoding in non ascii characters such as ebcdic
lines.name: English

lines.value: in practice most source code has some dependency on the platform for which it is designed even if a programmer uses a platform independent programming language like java it is hard to write a large useful program that is totally independent of its environment
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the manufacturer upgrades a platform or the platform is superseded the code may no longer work without changes and becomes legacy code
lines.name: English

lines.value: a large part of the task of a software engineer is to continually alter code to prevent this
lines.name: English

lines.value: while the term usually refers to source code it can also apply to executable code that no longer runs on a later version of a system or requires a compatibility layer to do so
lines.name: English

lines.value: an example would be a classic macintosh application which will not run natively on mac os x but runs inside the classic environment or a win16 application running on windows xp using the windows on windows feature in xp
lines.name: English

lines.value: more recently the software engineering community has developed other interpretations for the term legacy code
lines.name: English

lines.value: among the most prevalent are source code inherited from someone else and source code inherited from an older version of the software
lines.name: English

lines.value: michael feathers introduced a definition of legacy code as code without tests which reflects the perspective of legacy code being difficult to work with in part due to a lack of automated regression tests
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also defined characterization tests to start putting legacy code under test
lines.name: English

lines.value: ginny hendry characterized creation of code as a challenge to current coders to create code that is like other legacies in our lives like the antiques heirlooms and stories that are cherished and lovingly passed down from one generation to the next
lines.name: English

lines.value: what if legacy code was something we took pride in
lines.name: English

lines.value: * legacy system
lines.name: English

lines.value: <references >
lines.name: English

lines.value: buddhism in japan has been practiced since its official introduction in 552 ce according to the nihon shoki from baekje korea by buddhist monks
lines.name: English

lines.value: buddhism has had a major influence on the development of japanese society and remains an influential aspect of the culture to this day
lines.name: English

lines.value: in modern times japan's most popular schools of buddhism are pure land buddhism nichiren buddhism shingon buddhism and zen
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of 2008 approximately 34% of the japanese identify as buddhists and the number has been growing since the 1980s in terms of membership in organized religion
lines.name: English

lines.value: however in terms of practice 75% practice some form of buddhism compared with 90% practicing shinto thus most japanese practice both religions to some extent shinbutsu-shugo
lines.name: English

lines.value: about 60% of the japanese have a butsudan buddhist shrine in their homes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the arrival of buddhism in china is ultimately a consequence of the first contacts between china and central asia where buddhism had spread from the indian subcontinent
lines.name: English

lines.value: these contacts occurred with the opening of the silk road in the 2nd century bce following the travels of zhang qian between 138 and 126 bce
lines.name: English

lines.value: these contacts culminated with the official introduction of buddhism in china in 67 ce
lines.name: English

lines.value: historians generally agree that by the middle of the 1st century the religion had penetrated to areas north of the huai river in china
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to the book of liang which was written in 635 five buddhist monks from gandhara traveled to japan in 467
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time they referred to japan as fusang (), the name of a mythological country to the extreme east beyond the sea
lines.name: English

lines.value: although there are records of buddhist monks from china coming to japan before the asuka period the official introduction of buddhism to japan is dated to 552 in nihon shoki when king seong of baekje 聖明王 now western korea sent a mission to the emperor kinmei that included buddhist monks or nuns together with an image of buddha and a number of sutras to introduce buddhism
lines.name: English

lines.value: the powerful soga clan played a key role in the early spread of buddhism in the country
lines.name: English

lines.value: initial uptake of the new faith was slow and buddhism only started to spread some years later when empress suiko openly encouraged the acceptance of buddhism among all japanese people
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to legend in japan in 552 there was an attempt to destroy a tooth relic one of the first of buddha's to arrive in the country it was hit by a hammer into an anvil the hammer and anvil were destroyed but the tooth was not
lines.name: English

lines.value: on january 15 593 soga no umako ordered relics of buddha deposited inside the foundation stone under the pillar of a pagoda at asuka dera
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 607 in order to obtain copies of sutras an imperial envoy was dispatched to sui china
lines.name: English

lines.value: as time progressed and the number of buddhist clergy increased the offices of sojo archbishop and sozu bishop were created
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 627 there were 46 buddhist temples 816 buddhist priests and 569 buddhist nuns in japan
lines.name: English

lines.value: the initial period saw the six great chinese schools called in japanese introduced to the japanese archipelago
lines.name: English

lines.value: the late nara period saw the introduction of tangmi esoteric buddhism japanese mikkyo to japan from china by kukai and saicho who founded shingon buddhism and the tendai school respectively
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the heian period the capital was shifted from nara to kyoto
lines.name: English

lines.value: monasteries became centers of powers even establishing armies of sohei warrior monks
lines.name: English

lines.value: shinto and buddhism became the dominant religions maintaining a balance until the meiji restoration
lines.name: English

lines.value: the kamakura period was a period of crises in which the control of the country moved from the imperial aristocracy to the samurai
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1185 the kamakura shogunate was established at kamakura
lines.name: English

lines.value: this period saw the introduction of the two schools that had perhaps the greatest impact on the country the schools of pure land buddhism promulgated by evangelists such as genshin and articulated by monks such as honen which emphasize salvation through faith in amitabha and remain the largest buddhist sect in japan and throughout asia and zen promulgated by monks such as eisai and dogen which emphasize liberation through the insight of meditation which were equally rapidly adopted by the upper classes and had a profound impact on the culture of japan
lines.name: English

lines.value: additionally it was during the kamakura period that the influential monk nichiren began teaching devotion to the lotus sutra
lines.name: English

lines.value: eventually his disciples formed their own school of nichiren buddhism which includes various sects that have their own interpretations of nichiren's teachings
lines.name: English

lines.value: nichiren buddhism established the foundation of japanese buddhism in the thirteenth century
lines.name: English

lines.value: the school is known for its sociopolitical activism and looks to reform society through faith
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the muromachi period zen particularly the rinzai school obtained the help of the ashikaga shogunate and the emperor of japan and accomplished considerable development
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the sengoku period of war japan was reunited in the azuchi momoyama period
lines.name: English

lines.value: this decreased the power of buddhism which had become a strong political and military force in japan
lines.name: English

lines.value: neo confucianism and shinto gained influence at the expense of buddhism which came under strict state control
lines.name: English

lines.value: japan closed itself off to the rest of the world
lines.name: English

lines.value: the only traders to be allowed were dutchmen admitted to the island of dejima
lines.name: English

lines.value: new doctrines and methods were not to be introduced nor were new temples and schools
lines.name: English

lines.value: the only exception was the obaku lineage which was introduced in the 17th century during the edo period by ingen a chinese monk
lines.name: English

lines.value: ingen had been a member of the linji school the chinese equivalent of rinzai which had developed separately from the japanese branch for hundreds of years
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus when ingen journeyed to japan following the fall of the ming dynasty to the manchu people his teachings were seen as a separate school
lines.name: English

lines.value: the obaku school was named after mount huangbo (), which had been ingen's home in china
lines.name: English

lines.value: also notable during the period was the publication of an exceptionally high quality reprint of the ming era tripiṭaka by tetsugen doko a renowned master of the obaku school
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the meiji restoration in 1868 the new government adopted a strong anti buddhist attitude and a movement to eradicate buddhism and bring shinto to ascendancy arose throughout the country due to the strong connections of buddhism to the shoguns
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the meiji period 1868-1912 after a coup in 1868 japan abandoned its feudal system and opened up to western modernism
lines.name: English

lines.value: shinto became the state religion
lines.name: English

lines.value: within the buddhist establishment the western world was seen as a threat as well as a challenge to stand up to
lines.name: English

lines.value: buddhist institutions had a simple choice adapt or perish
lines.name: English

lines.value: rinzai and soto zen chose to adapt trying to modernize zen in accord with western insights while simultaneously maintaining a japanese identity
lines.name: English

lines.value: other schools and buddhism in general simply saw their influence wane
lines.name: English

lines.value: the edict of april 1872 ended the status of the buddhist precepts as state law and allowed monks to marry and to eat meat
lines.name: English

lines.value: this codification of a secularized lifestyle for the monk coupled with the revival of the emperor system and development of state shinto were fundamental in desacralizing buddhism and pushing it to the margins of society
lines.name: English

lines.value: japanese identity was being articulated in nihonjinron the japanese uniqueness theory
lines.name: English

lines.value: a broad range of subjects was taken as typical of japanese culture
lines.name: English

lines.value: d t suzuki contributed to the nihonjinron by taking zen as the distinctive token of asian spirituality showing its unique character in the japanese culture
lines.name: English

lines.value: nichirenism was one particular expression of japanese buddhist nationalism
lines.name: English

lines.value: during world war ii almost all buddhists temples strongly supported japan's militarization
lines.name: English

lines.value: in contrast a few individuals such as ichikawa haku and giro seno'o were targeted and the soka kyoiku gakkai a nichiren lay believers organization was ultimately banned by military authorities
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the 1940s leaders of both honmon hokkeshu and sokka gakkai were imprisoned for their defiance of wartime government religious policy which mandated display of reverence for state shinto post world war ii there was a high demand for buddhist priests who glorified fallen soldiers and gave funerals and posthumous names causing a strong revival
lines.name: English

lines.value: however due to secularization and materialism buddhism and religion in general continued to decline
lines.name: English

lines.value: japan has seen a growth in post war movements of lay believers of buddhism and a decline in traditional buddhism in the 20th century with roughly 100 buddhist organizations disappearing every year
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of 2008 approximately 34% of the japanese identify as buddhists and the number has been growing since the 1980s as buddhists were 27% in 1984
lines.name: English

lines.value: still around 90% of japanese funerals are conducted according to buddhist rites
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1963 tamamuro taijo coined the term funeral buddhism that came to be used to describe traditional buddhism in japan as the religion engaged in funerary rites and removed from the spiritual needs of people
lines.name: English

lines.value: contrary to the ritualistic practice of traditional buddhism a revived modern form of nichiren buddhism led by lay believers soka gakkai ...grew rapidly in the chaos of post war japan from about 3000 members in 1951 to over 8 million members in 2000 and has established schools colleges and a university as well as cultural institutions
lines.name: English

lines.value: a study about the reason for the growth in lay believers and increased engagement in society attributes the cause to nichiren teachings of social responsibility in the tradition of nichiren buddhism however we find the lotus sutra linked to a view of social responsibility that is distinctive
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to an academic study lay believers of buddhism “… offer an alternative view of japan where their form of buddhism would form the religious foundation of a peaceful and psychologically and materially enriched society

lines.value: japanese culture maintained an uneasy relation to buddhist culture
lines.name: English

lines.value: while the chinese culture was admired buddhism was also regarded as a strange influence
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the kamakura 1185-1333 and muromachi 1336-1573 buddhism or the buddhist institutions had a great influence on japanese society
lines.name: English

lines.value: buddhist institutions were used by the shogunate to control the country
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the edo 1600-1868 this power was constricted to be followed by persecutions at the beginning of the meiji restoration 1868-1912
lines.name: English

lines.value: buddhist temples played a major administrative role during the edo period through the danka or terauke system
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this japanese citizens were required to register at their local buddhist temples and obtain a certification terauke which became necessary to function in society
lines.name: English

lines.value: at first this system was put into place to suppress christianity but over time it took on the larger role of census and population control
lines.name: English

lines.value: in japan buddhist art started to develop as the country converted to buddhism in 548
lines.name: English

lines.value: some tiles from the asuka period shown above the first period following the conversion of the country to buddhism display a strikingly classical style with ample hellenistic dress and realistically rendered body shape characteristic of greco buddhist art
lines.name: English

lines.value: buddhist art became extremely varied in its expression
lines.name: English

lines.value: many elements of greco buddhist art remain to this day however such as the hercules inspiration behind the nio guardian deities in front of japanese buddhist temples or representations of the buddha reminiscent of greek art such as the buddha in kamakura
lines.name: English

lines.value: various other greco buddhist artistic influences can be found in the japanese buddhist pantheon the most striking being that of the japanese wind god fujin
lines.name: English

lines.value: in consistency with greek iconography for the wind god boreas the japanese wind god holds above his head with his two hands a draping or wind bag in the same general attitude
lines.name: English

lines.value: the abundance of hair has been kept in the japanese rendering as well as exaggerated facial features
lines.name: English

lines.value: another buddhist deity shukongoshin one of the wrath filled protector deities of buddhist temples in japan is also an interesting case of transmission of the image of the famous greek god heracles to east asia along the silk road
lines.name: English

lines.value: heracles was used in greco buddhist art to represent vajrapani the protector of the buddha and his representation was then used in china and japan to depict the protector gods of buddhist temples
lines.name: English

lines.value: the artistic inspiration from greek floral scrolls is found quite literally in the decoration of japanese roof tiles one of the only remaining element of wooden architecture throughout centuries
lines.name: English

lines.value: the clearest ones are from the 7th century nara temple building tiles some of them exactly depicting vines and grapes
lines.name: English

lines.value: these motifs have evolved towards more symbolic representations but essentially remain to this day in many japanese traditional buildings

lines.value: guillermo lora 31 october 1922 &ndash 17 may 2009 was a trotskyist leader in bolivia who was active in the revolutionary workers party por from the early 1940s and was its best known leader
lines.name: English

lines.value: lora became active in the por when it was in the process of building links with the bolivian labor movement most notably the federation of bolivian mine workers fstmb
lines.name: English

lines.value: following the por's participation in the 1952 bolivian national revolution its power was quickly circumscribed by the ruling revolutionary nationalist movement mnr
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1960s when a faction of the por sought to follow the example of che guevara and engage in guerrilla warfare lora led a second group generally referred to as por(masas that maintained its focus on the labor movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: though lora sympathized with the international committee of the fourth international his faction of the por did not affiliate with any international socialist grouping during the time
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1988 por(masas founded the liaison committee for the reconstruction of the fourth international cerci
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the years of military dictatorship in bolivia in the 1970s lora and his faction of the por were an important ally of juan lechin oquendo the president of the miners union
lines.name: English

lines.value: though it is far smaller than at its height in 1952 lora's por still remains as one of the largest trotskyist groups in bolivia
