lines.value: a surrogate key or synthetic key entity identifier system generated key database sequence number factless key technical key or arbitrary unique identifier in a database is a unique identifier for either an entity in the modeled world or an object in the database
lines.name: English

lines.value: the surrogate key is not derived from application data unlike a natural or business key which is derived from application data
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are at least two definitions of a surrogate an important distinction between a surrogate and a primary key depends on whether the database is a current database or a temporal database
lines.name: English

lines.value: since a current database stores only currently valid data there is a one to one correspondence between a surrogate in the modeled world and the primary key of the database
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this case the surrogate may be used as a primary key resulting in the term surrogate key
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a temporal database however there is a many to one relationship between primary keys and the surrogate
lines.name: English

lines.value: since there may be several objects in the database corresponding to a single surrogate we cannot use the surrogate as a primary key another attribute is required in addition to the surrogate to uniquely identify each object
lines.name: English

lines.value: although hall et al 1976 say nothing about this others have argued that a surrogate should have the following characteristics
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a current database the surrogate key can be the primary key generated by the database management system and not derived from any application data in the database
lines.name: English

lines.value: the only significance of the surrogate key is to act as the primary key
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is also possible that the surrogate key exists in addition to the database generated uuid for example an hr number for each employee other than the uuid of each employee
lines.name: English

lines.value: a surrogate key is frequently a sequential number e.g a sybase or sql server identity column a postgresql or informix ]).having the key independent of all other columns insulates the database relationships from changes in data values or database design making the database more agile and guarantees uniqueness
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a temporal database it is necessary to distinguish between the surrogate key and the business key
lines.name: English

lines.value: every row would have both a business key and a surrogate key
lines.name: English

lines.value: the surrogate key identifies one unique row in the database the business key identifies one unique entity of the modeled world
lines.name: English

lines.value: one table row represents a slice of time holding all the entity's attributes for a defined timespan
lines.name: English

lines.value: those slices depict the whole lifespan of one business entity
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example a table employeecontracts may hold temporal information to keep track of contracted working hours
lines.name: English

lines.value: the business key for one contract will be identical non-unique in both rows however the surrogate key for each row is unique
lines.name: English

lines.value: some database designers use surrogate keys systematically regardless of the suitability of other candidate keys while others will use a key already present in the data if there is one
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of the alternate names system-generated key describe the way of generating new surrogate values rather than the nature of the surrogate concept
lines.name: English

lines.value: approaches to generating surrogates include
lines.name: English

lines.value: surrogate keys do not change while the row exists
lines.name: English

lines.value: this has the following advantages
lines.name: English

lines.value: attributes that uniquely identify an entity might change which might invalidate the suitability of natural keys
lines.name: English

lines.value: consider the following example :an employee's network user name is chosen as a natural key
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon merging with another company new employees must be inserted
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of the new network user names create conflicts because their user names were generated independently when the companies were separate
lines.name: English

lines.value: in these cases generally a new attribute must be added to the natural key for example an original_company column
lines.name: English

lines.value: with a surrogate key only the table that defines the surrogate key must be changed
lines.name: English

lines.value: with natural keys all tables and possibly other related software that use the natural key will have to change
lines.name: English

lines.value: some problem domains do not clearly identify a suitable natural key
lines.name: English

lines.value: surrogate keys avoid choosing a natural key that might be incorrect
lines.name: English

lines.value: surrogate keys tend to be a compact data type such as a four byte integer
lines.name: English

lines.value: this allows the database to query the single key column faster than it could multiple columns
lines.name: English

lines.value: furthermore a non redundant distribution of keys causes the resulting b tree index to be completely balanced
lines.name: English

lines.value: surrogate keys are also less expensive to join fewer columns to compare than compound keys
lines.name: English

lines.value: while using several database application development systems drivers and object relational mapping systems such as ruby on rails or hibernate it is much easier to use an integer or guid surrogate keys for every table instead of natural keys in order to support database system agnostic operations and object to row mapping
lines.name: English

lines.value: when every table has a uniform surrogate key some tasks can be easily automated by writing the code in a table independent way
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is possible to design key values that follow a well known pattern or structure which can be automatically verified
lines.name: English

lines.value: for instance the keys that are intended to be used in some column of some table might be designed to look differently from those that are intended to be used in another column or table thereby simplifying the detection of application errors in which the keys have been misplaced
lines.name: English

lines.value: however this characteristic of the surrogate keys should never be used to drive any of the logic of the applications themselves as this would violate the principles of database normalization
lines.name: English

lines.value: the values of generated surrogate keys have no relationship to the real world meaning of the data held in a row
lines.name: English

lines.value: when inspecting a row holding a foreign key reference to another table using a surrogate key the meaning of the surrogate key's row cannot be discerned from the key itself
lines.name: English

lines.value: every foreign key must be joined to see the related data item
lines.name: English

lines.value: this can also make auditing more difficult as incorrect data is not obvious
lines.name: English

lines.value: surrogate keys are unnatural for data that is exported and shared
lines.name: English

lines.value: a particular difficulty is that tables from two otherwise identical schemas for example a test schema and a development schema can hold records that are equivalent in a business sense but have different keys
lines.name: English

lines.value: this can be mitigated by not exporting surrogate keys except as transient data most obviously in executing applications that have a live connection to the database
lines.name: English

lines.value: when surrogate keys supplant natural keys then domain specific referential integrity will be compromised
lines.name: English

lines.value: relational databases assume a unique index is applied to a table's primary key
lines.name: English

lines.value: the unique index serves two purposes i to enforce entity integrity since primary key data must be unique across rows and ii to quickly search for rows when queried
lines.name: English

lines.value: since surrogate keys replace a table's identifying attributes the natural key and since the identifying attributes are likely to be those queried then the query optimizer is forced to perform a full table scan when fulfilling likely queries
lines.name: English

lines.value: the remedy to the full table scan is to apply indexes on the identifying attributes or sets of them
lines.name: English

lines.value: where such sets are themselves a candidate key the index can be a unique index
lines.name: English

lines.value: these additional indexes however will take up disk space and slow down inserts and deletes
lines.name: English

lines.value: surrogate keys can result in duplicate values in any natural keys
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is part of the implementation to ensure that such duplicates should not be possible
lines.name: English

lines.value: because surrogate keys are unnatural flaws can appear when modeling the business requirements
lines.name: English

lines.value: business requirements relying on the natural key then need to be translated to the surrogate key
lines.name: English

lines.value: a strategy is to draw a clear distinction between the logical model in which surrogate keys do not appear and the physical implementation of that model to ensure that the logical model is correct and reasonably well normalised and to ensure that the physical model is a correct implementation of the logical model
lines.name: English

lines.value: proprietary information can be leaked if sequential key generators are used
lines.name: English

lines.value: by subtracting a previously generated sequential key from a recently generated sequential key one could learn the number of rows inserted during that time period
lines.name: English

lines.value: this could expose for example the number of transactions or new accounts per period
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are a few ways to overcome this problem
lines.name: English

lines.value: sequentially generated surrogate keys can imply that events with a higher key value occurred after events with a lower value
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is not necessarily true because such values do not guarantee time sequence as it is possible for inserts to fail and leave gaps which may be filled at a later time
lines.name: English

lines.value: if chronology is important then date and time must be separately recorded
lines.name: English

lines.value: helenius acron or acro was a roman commentator and grammarian probably of the 3rd century ad but whose precise date is not known
lines.name: English

lines.value: helenius acron is known to have written on terence adelphi and eunuchus at least and horace
lines.name: English

lines.value: these commentaries on horace are now lost but are referred to by the grammarian charisius
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is some evidence for a commentary on persius
lines.name: English

lines.value: scholia attributed to acron appear in manuscripts of horace there are three recensions known the earliest dating to the 5th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fragments which remain of the work on horace though much mutilated are valuable as containing the remarks of the older commentators quintus terentius scaurus and others
lines.name: English

lines.value: the attribution to acron however is not found before the 15th century and is doubtful
lines.name: English

lines.value: fragments of acron's writing may also appear in pomponius porphyrion
lines.name: English

lines.value: kallithea greek kaaaioea meaning the best view is the 8th largest municipality in greece 100641 inhabitants 2011 census and the 4th biggest in the athens urban area following municipalities of athens piraeus and peristeri
lines.name: English

lines.value: additionally it is the 2nd most densely populated municipality in greece with 21192 inhabitants km²
lines.name: English

lines.value: the municipality has an area of 4.749 km 2
lines.name: English

lines.value: actual the community reports a number of close to 200.000 inhabitants
lines.name: English

lines.value: the center of kallithea davaki square lies at a distance of to the south of the athens city center syntagma square and to the north east of the piraeus photo 1
lines.name: English

lines.value: kallithea extends from the filopappou and sikelia hills in the north to phaleron bay in the south ; its two other sides consist of syngrou avenue to the east border to the towns of nea smyrni and palaio faliro and the ilisos river to the west border to the towns of tavros and moschato photo 2).the site on which the city was developed covers the biggest part of the area to the south of athens protected in ancient times 5th century bc by the long walls to the west and the phalerum wall to the east photo 3
lines.name: English

lines.value: somewhere within this area the ancient town of xypete lay
lines.name: English

lines.value: the town and its citizens are mentioned among other places in plato's dialogs
lines.name: English

lines.value: the plans for the establishment of the new city of kallithea were officially approved in december 1884
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the longitudinal axis of the town thiseos avenue the athens to phaleron tramway once ran from the beginning 1850 to 1955 and the end of its operations
lines.name: English

lines.value: near the center of the town the shooting range skopeftirion was built to house events of the first modern olympic games the 1896 summer olympics and these first modern games took place in three venues the refurbished ancient stadium of athens panathinaiko stadium ne of kallithea the neo phaliron velodrome currently karaiskaki stadium sw of kallithea and the kallithea shooting range skopeftirion
lines.name: English

lines.value: events of the athens 2004 olympic games were also sited in the district of kallithea notably handball and taekwondo in the new sports pavilion faliro by the bottom of syngrou avenue and beach volleyball in the olympic beach volleyball center on kallithea bay tzitzifies
lines.name: English

lines.value: between the first modern games 1896 and the recent 2004 olympic games in the city kallithea grew significantly
lines.name: English

lines.value: initially the tramway depot and workshop were built here in 1910 followed by the harokopios graduate school 1925 and the panteios graduate school of political sciences 1928
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1920s the town was flooded by thousands of refugees following the greco turkish war 1919-1922 the asia minor catastrophe 1922 and the treaty of lausanne 1923
lines.name: English

lines.value: these refugees arrived in kallithea mainly from the south black sea pontus from ancient greek cities such as sinope now sinop turkey sampsus now samsun turkey kerasus now giresun turkey trapezous trebizond now trabzon turkey tripolis now tirebolu turkey argyroupolis now gumushane turkey and other remnants of the late byzantine empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: a few had arrived earlier 1919 from the north and east russian coasts of the black sea from places such as odessos odessa marioupolis mariupol the sea of azov and elsewhere after the failed attempt of the western allies greece included against the young bolshevik state during the russian civil war
lines.name: English

lines.value: black sea immigrants of greek origin also settled in kallithea in the 1930s as a result of the change of soviet policy toward ethnic groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: their origins were mainly in the east coast of the black sea batumi sukhumi novorossiysk anapa etc the first refugees settled originally near the site of the first olympic shooting range 1896 until they were gradually transferred to new dwellings
lines.name: English

lines.value: after its evacuation the building bound with the shooting range served as a school until the nazi occupation of 1941 when it was converted to a prison
lines.name: English

lines.value: the prison of kallithea was demolished in 1966 ;among others fighters of the greek resistance and victims of the greek civil war had been jailed there such as nikos beloyannis
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1990s after the dissolution of the soviet union a new wave of greek immigrants arrived in kallithea from the east coast of the black sea from the caucasus highlands in georgia as well as from distant greek settlements in kazakhstan and uzbekistan where their black sea greek ancestors were expelled during joseph stalin's regime in the 1930s
lines.name: English

lines.value: south kallithea tzitzifies is associated with the development of greek folk music particularly rebetiko and later laiko
lines.name: English

lines.value: popular composers and singers once performed here ; markos vamvakaris vassilis tsitsanis yannis papaioannou marika ninou sotiria bellou manolis chiotis mary linda giorgos zampetas stelios kazantzidis marinella poly panou and viki moscholiou
lines.name: English

lines.value: kallithea houses two universities harokopio university and panteion university
lines.name: English

lines.value: an even notable school in kallithea is sivitanidios school one of the oldest technical school in greece
lines.name: English

lines.value: until 2004 south kallithea tzitzifies housed the only horse track in greece ippodromos hippodrome which later moved to markopoulon near eleftherios venizelos airport
lines.name: English

lines.value: kallithea houses numerous cultural associations and several sport clubs the most well known of which are kallithea fc soccer esperos basketball volleyball handball and also soccer in an earlier period and ikaros kallitheas a multisport club founded in 1991 originally as ikaros nea smyrni
lines.name: English

lines.value: kallithea had another important club esperides kallithea with many titles in women basketball
lines.name: English

lines.value: this club merged to ikaros kallithea in 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: the main roads of kallithea are andrea syngrou avenue towards eastern athens and poseidonos avenue towards piraeus and the southern suburbs
lines.name: English

lines.value: kallithea is served by metro line 1 stations kallithea and tavros by the tram stations kallithea and tzitzifies and numerous bus and trolley bus linesconnect kallithea to almost every destination in metropolitan athens
lines.name: English

lines.value: the is a japanese railway line connecting toyohashi station in toyohashi aichi with tatsuno station in tatsuno nagano operated by central japan railway company jr central
lines.name: English

lines.value: the line links eastern aichi prefecture and southern nagano prefecture through northwestern shizuoka prefecture
lines.name: English

lines.value: it goes through steep mountains as well as cities such as iida and ina
lines.name: English

lines.value: the line was originally four different private railway lines the first of which opened in 1897
lines.name: English

lines.value: the line has an unusually high number of stations some of which have since lost their nearby communities due to depopulation
lines.name: English

lines.value: traveling the entire length of the 195.7 km line by local trains takes six hours
lines.name: English

lines.value: the limited express runs between toyohashi and iida twice a day
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rapid runs between iida and okaya
lines.name: English

lines.value: local service is generally divided into three parts by hon nagashino and tenryukyo stations
lines.name: English

lines.value: the section near toyohashi functions as commuter rail for the city while the section between hon nagashino and tenryukyo is a mountain railway with fewer passengers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the toyokawa railway opened the section from toyohashi to toyokawa in 1897 extending the line to omi in 1900
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the northern end the ina electric railway opened the tatsuno to ina matsushima section electrified at 1200 v dc in 1909 extending the line to tenryukyo in sections between 1911 and 1927
lines.name: English

lines.value: the horaitera railway opened the omi to mikawa kawai section in 1923 and electrified it at 1500 v dc in 1925 in conjunction with the electrification of the toyohashi to omi section the same year
lines.name: English

lines.value: the toyohashi to toyokawa section was double tracked the following year
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sanshin railway opened the tenryukyo to kadoshima section as an electrified 1500 v dc line in 1932 the mikawa kawai to toei section and all subsequent stages as an electrified line in 1933 and connected the two sections completing the line in 1936
lines.name: English

lines.value: all four companies were nationalised in 1943
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1955 the overhead line voltage of the tatsuno to tenryukyo section was increased to 1500 v dcctc signalling was commissioned on the line between 1983 and 1984 and freight services ceased in 1996
lines.name: English

lines.value: * hon nagashino station a 23 km line to mikawa taguchi electrified at 1500 v dc opened between 1930 and 1932
lines.name: English

lines.value: two 762mm gauge forest railways connected to this line the damine forest railway which connected at the station of the same name consisted of a 19 km main line including a tunnel and a 7 km branch operated between 1932 and 1960 the taguchi forest railway connected at the terminus station consisted of a 10 km main line and a 6 km branch operated between 1934 and 1963
lines.name: English

lines.value: both forest railways were notable for initially employing people and large dogs to haul the empty wagons upgrade which then rolled downhill when loaded
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mikawa taguchi line closed following flood damage in 1968
lines.name: English

lines.value: * chubu tenryu station construction started on a 35 km line to tenryu futamata on the hamanako line in 1967
lines.name: English

lines.value: proposed to involve 20 bridges and 14 tunnels about 13 km of roadbed and about 50% of the overall work had been completed when construction was abandoned in 1980
lines.name: English

lines.value: a follow up to newton's cannon the book is set in 1722 and continues the alternate history where isaac newton discovers that alchemy works and a powerful science is built upon it

lines.value: william gordon cornwallis eliot 4th earl of st germans 14 december 1829 - 19 march 1881 known as lord eliot from 1864 to 1877 was a british diplomat and liberal politician
lines.name: English

lines.value: eliot was born at port eliot cornwall the third but eldest surviving son of edward granville eliot 3rd earl of st germans and his wife jemima nee cornwallis
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was educated at eton college and then joined the diplomatic service
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served as attache at hanover from 1849 to 1853 as attache at lisbon from 1851 to 1853 as 2nd paid attache at berlin from 1853 to 1857 as 1st paid attache at constantinople from 1857 to 1858 as 1st paid attache at st petersburg from 1858 to 1859 as secretary of legation at rio de janeiro in 1859 as secretary of legation at athens from 1859 to 1861 as secretary of legation at lisbon from 1860 to 1861 and from 1864 to 1865 as charge d'affaires at rio de janeiro from 1861 to 1863 and as acting secretary of legation at washington dc from 1863 to 1864
lines.name: English

lines.value: he resigned in 1865 and was elected member of parliament for devonport in 1866 a seat he held until 1868
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1870 he was summoned to the house of lords as through a writ of acceleration in his father's junior title of baron eliot
lines.name: English

lines.value: lord st germans died unmarried in march 1881 aged 51 and is buried near his mother at kensal green cemetery
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was succeeded by his younger brother henry
lines.name: English

lines.value: bruck an der mur is a city of some 13500 people located in the district bruck murzzuschlag in the austrian state of styria
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is located at the confluence of the mur and murz rivers
lines.name: English

lines.value: its manufacturing includes metal products and paper
lines.name: English

lines.value: bruck is located on the graz to vienna main line and is an important regional rail junction
lines.name: English

lines.value: the earliest surviving record of bruck dates from the time of king ludovicus ii germanicus when it was identified in a record dated 20 november 860 as ad pruccam a manor of the archbishopric of salzburg
lines.name: English

lines.value: the settlement then identified with this name was in the location currently occupied by the suburb now called st ruprecht
lines.name: English

lines.value: the settlement then located at what is now the centre of bruck is identified in the ninth century record as muorica kimundi i.e the mouth of the murz river
lines.name: English

lines.value: the town was refounded in 1263 by king otakar ii of bohemia who was responsible for surrounding bruck with its city walls
lines.name: English

lines.value: bruck received its town privileges in 1277 from king rudolph von habsburg who in 1273 succeeded otakar
lines.name: English

lines.value: bruck an der mur was an important medieval trade center specializing in iron work
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is a 15th-century gothic church in the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the centre there is also the famous kornmesser house built in the venetian style by pankraz kornmess in the 15th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is also the iron well with its famous lace like dome
lines.name: English

lines.value: the castle of landskron burned down in the great fire of 1792
lines.name: English

lines.value: after that fire just two of 166 houses were left standing
lines.name: English

lines.value: near bruck is a recreation area called weitental
lines.name: English

lines.value: every august a well known artist and clown festival called murenschalk is held
lines.name: English

lines.value: the young people of bruck an der mur have been known to criticize the mayor bernd rosenberger spo who unconditionally increased the police presence on the streets
lines.name: English

lines.value: they argue that this policy has the objective of harming the nightlife and harassing young people
lines.name: English

lines.value: clement claiborne clay december 13 1816 - january 3 1882 also known as c
lines.name: English

lines.value: c clay jr was a united states senator democrat from the state of alabama from 1853 to 1861 and a confederate states senator from alabama from 1862 to 1864
lines.name: English

lines.value: his portrait appeared on the confederate one dollar note 4th issue and later
lines.name: English

lines.value: clement claiborne clay was born to clement comer clay and susanna claiborne withers a daughter of well off planter john withers in huntsville alabama
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had a strong political pedigree he was the oldest son of clement comer clay a us senator and governor of alabama
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was also a third cousin of henry clay the noted statesman from kentucky
lines.name: English

lines.value: clay attended the huntsville green academy then studied at the university of alabama at tuscaloosa in 1833-1834
lines.name: English

lines.value: in august 1834 at the age seventeen he received an ab degree
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served as his father's secretary in 1835-1837 after clement clay sr was elected as a governor of alabama
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1837 he and his brother john withers clay both entered the university of virginia their brother hugh lawson clay joined them later
lines.name: English

lines.value: in july 1839 clay obtained a bachelor of laws degree after studying with john b minor known for his rigor and was admitted to the alabama bar on october 2 1839
lines.name: English

lines.value: on february 1 1843 he married virginia tunstall who was then 18 years old
lines.name: English

lines.value: they had one child who died stillborn
lines.name: English

lines.value: after clement's death in 1882 virginia remarried to david clopton a judge and was known as virginia clay clopton
lines.name: English

lines.value: virginia wrote belle of the fifties a memoir with new york journalist ada sterling published in 1904 and reissued in 1905
lines.name: English

lines.value: belle was one of three memoirs by southern women particularly recommended by the united daughters of the confederacy to its membership for studying
lines.name: English

lines.value: her book became part of the discourse about the lost cause and the burnished memory of the antebellum south
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1839-1846 c c clay jr practiced law in a family law firm in 1846-1848 he served as madison county judge
lines.name: English

lines.value: clay was a member of the alabama state house of representatives in 1842 and in 1844-1845
lines.name: English

lines.value: he ran for the united states congress in 1850 but did not succeed after losing to an incumbent
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1853 he was elected by the alabama legislature to serve in the united states senate in a term beginning march 4 1853 and was reelected in 1857
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to the legislature's delay in filling the position he served from november 29 1853 to january 21 1861
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the senate he defended the state's rights during the political debates of the time and opposed henry clay
lines.name: English

lines.value: he withdrew from the senate when alabama seceded from the union on january 11 1861 before the american civil war broke out
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was subsequently elected by the alabama confederate legislature as senator in the first confederate congress
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served there from 1862 until 1864 acting as a supporter of jefferson davis
lines.name: English

lines.value: along with jacob thompson clay was a part of the confederate war department effort to create a network of secret agents to conduct espionage and sabotage
lines.name: English

lines.value: in may 1864 president davis sent clay to canada with a secret mission to coordinate activities of the southern sympathizers in the great lakes area including members of the order of the sons of liberty and the knights of the golden circle
lines.name: English

lines.value: clay took part in a secret meeting with john hay president abraham lincoln's aide at niagara falls canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was suspected that thompson and clay had employed john wilkes booth for some services before he assassinated president abraham lincoln
lines.name: English

lines.value: president andrew johnson signed an order to arrest clay
lines.name: English

lines.value: after learning from a newspaper that a reward was issued for his capture clay who initially planned to escape to mexico turned himself in to general james h wilson in macon georgia in may 1865
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was arrested and held in fort monroe in hampton virginia until april 1866
lines.name: English

lines.value: former confederate president jefferson davis was also held in fort monroe but was never tried he was released in 1867
lines.name: English

lines.value: clay was imprisoned by the united states government under impression that he was involved in the plot to assassinate president abraham lincoln
lines.name: English

lines.value: virginia clay played some role in her husband's release as she went to washington dc and personally pleaded with president johnson
lines.name: English

lines.value: the clays returned to alabama and struggled to rebuild their lives living on a farm
lines.name: English

lines.value: clay tried to practice as an attorney and entered insurance business in huntsville however without much success due to poor health ultimately returning to his farm in january 1882
lines.name: English

lines.value: he died in 1882 in madison county besieged by debts and health problems and is interred at maple hill cemetery
lines.name: English

lines.value: soyuz tm 5 was the fifth cosmonaut carrying spacecraft to visit the russian space station mir
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was launched on june 7 1988 carrying the mir ep 2 mission's three person crew
lines.name: English

lines.value: this week long stay on mir occurred during the third long duration mir expedition mir eo 3
lines.name: English

lines.value: the crew of ep 2 returned to earth aboard soyuz tm 4 while the tm 5 spacecraft remained docked to mir acting as the lifeboat for the long duration crew
lines.name: English

lines.value: on september 7 1988 the tm 5 spacecraft undocked from mir and landed mir ep 3 mission's two person visiting crew
lines.name: English

lines.value: the de orbit procedures for soyuz were revised after this flight as multiple issues almost prevented the descent module's safe de orbit and landing
lines.name: English

lines.value: soyuz tm 5 launched on 1988 june 7 and arrived at mir on june 9 carrying the second bulgarian in space alexandrov not to be confused with the soviet cosmonaut of the same name
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became the first bulgarian to reach a soviet space station georgi ivanov failed to reach salyut 6 on soyuz 33 in 1979—alexandrov was his backup
lines.name: English

lines.value: their launch had been advanced by 2 weeks late in the planning stages to improve lighting conditions for the rozhen astronomical experiment
lines.name: English

lines.value: on september 5 cosmonauts lyakhov and mohmand undocked from mir
lines.name: English

lines.value: they jettisoned the orbital module and made ready for deorbit burn to return to earth
lines.name: English

lines.value: during descent the spacecraft experienced a computer software problem combined with a sensor problem
lines.name: English

lines.value: this caused their landing to be delayed by a full day
lines.name: English

lines.value: the descent module where they spent this 24-hour period had no sanitary facilities
lines.name: English

lines.value: they would not have been able to redock with mir because they had discarded the docking system along with the orbital module
lines.name: English

lines.value: reentry occurred as normal on september 7
lines.name: English

lines.value: following this incident the soviets decided that on future missions they would retain the orbital module until after deorbit burn as they had done on the soyuz ferry flights
lines.name: English

lines.value: gastroenteritis also known as infectious diarrhea is inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract that involves the stomach and small intestine
lines.name: English

lines.value: symptoms may include diarrhea vomiting and abdominal pain
lines.name: English

lines.value: fever lack of energy and dehydration may also occur
lines.name: English

lines.value: this typically lasts less than two weeks
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is not related to influenza though it has been called the stomach flu
lines.name: English

lines.value: gastroenteritis can be due to infections by viruses bacteria parasites and fungus
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most common cause is viruses
lines.name: English

lines.value: in children rotavirus is the most common cause of severe disease
lines.name: English

lines.value: in adults norovirus and campylobacter are common
lines.name: English

lines.value: transmission may occur due to eating improperly prepared foods drinking contaminated water or through close contact with an individual who is infected
lines.name: English

lines.value: testing to confirm the diagnosis is typically not needed
lines.name: English

lines.value: prevention includes hand washing with soap drinking clean water proper disposal of human waste and breastfeeding babies instead of using formula
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rotavirus vaccine is recommended in children
lines.name: English

lines.value: treatment involves getting enough fluids
lines.name: English

lines.value: for mild or moderate cases this can typically be achieved by drinking oral rehydration solution a combination of water salts and sugar
lines.name: English

lines.value: in those who are breast fed continued breastfeeding is recommended
lines.name: English

lines.value: for more severe cases intravenous fluids may be needed
lines.name: English

lines.value: fluids may also be given by a nasogastric tube
lines.name: English

lines.value: zinc supplementation is recommended in children
lines.name: English

lines.value: antibiotics are generally not needed
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2015 two billion cases of gastroenteritis resulted in 1.3 million deaths globally
lines.name: English

lines.value: children and those in the developing world are affected the most
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2011 about 1.7 billion cases resulting in about 700000 deaths of children under the age of five
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the developing world children less than two years of age frequently get six or more infections a year
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is less common in adults partly due to the development of immunity
lines.name: English

lines.value: gastroenteritis typically involves both diarrhea and vomiting or less commonly presents with only one or the other
lines.name: English

lines.value: abdominal cramping may also be present
lines.name: English

lines.value: signs and symptoms usually begin 12 72 hours after contracting the infectious agent
lines.name: English

lines.value: if due to a viral agent the condition usually resolves within one week
lines.name: English

lines.value: some viral causes may also be associated with fever fatigue headache and muscle pain
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the stool is bloody the cause is less likely to be viral and more likely to be bacterial
lines.name: English

lines.value: some bacterial infections may be associated with severe abdominal pain and may persist for several weeks
lines.name: English

lines.value: children infected with rotavirus usually make a full recovery within three to eight days
lines.name: English

lines.value: however in poor countries treatment for severe infections is often out of reach and persistent diarrhea is common
lines.name: English

lines.value: dehydration is a common complication of diarrhea and a child with a significant degree of dehydration may have a prolonged capillary refill poor skin turgor and abnormal breathing
lines.name: English

lines.value: repeat infections are typically seen in areas with poor sanitation and malnutrition stunted growth and long term cognitive delays can result
lines.name: English

lines.value: reactive arthritis occurs in 1% of people following infections with campylobacter species and guillain barre syndrome occurs in 0.1%
lines.name: English

lines.value: hemolytic uremic syndrome hus may occur due to infection with shiga toxin producing escherichia coli or shigella species causing low platelet counts poor kidney function and low red blood cell count due to their breakdown
lines.name: English

lines.value: children are more predisposed to getting hus than adults
lines.name: English

lines.value: some viral infections may produce benign infantile seizures
lines.name: English

lines.value: viruses particularly rotavirus and the bacteria escherichia coli and campylobacter species are the primary causes of gastroenteritis
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are however many other infectious agents that can cause this syndrome
lines.name: English

lines.value: non infectious causes are seen on occasion but they are less likely than a viral or bacterial cause
lines.name: English

lines.value: risk of infection is higher in children due to their lack of immunity and relatively poor hygiene
lines.name: English

lines.value: rotavirus norovirus adenovirus and astrovirus are known to cause viral gastroenteritis
lines.name: English

lines.value: rotavirus is the most common cause of gastroenteritis in children and produces similar rates in both the developed and developing world
lines.name: English

lines.value: viruses cause about 70% of episodes of infectious diarrhea in the pediatric age group
lines.name: English

lines.value: rotavirus is a less common cause in adults due to acquired immunity
lines.name: English

lines.value: norovirus is the cause in about 18% of all cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: norovirus is the leading cause of gastroenteritis among adults in america causing greater than 90% of outbreaks
lines.name: English

lines.value: these localized epidemics typically occur when groups of people spend time in close physical proximity to each other such as on cruise ships in hospitals or in restaurants
lines.name: English

lines.value: people may remain infectious even after their diarrhea has ended
lines.name: English

lines.value: norovirus is the cause of about 10% of cases in children
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the developed world campylobacter jejuni is the primary cause of bacterial gastroenteritis with half of these cases associated with exposure to poultry
lines.name: English

lines.value: in children bacteria are the cause in about 15% of cases with the most common types being escherichia coli salmonella shigella and campylobacter species
lines.name: English

lines.value: if food becomes contaminated with bacteria and remains at room temperature for a period of several hours the bacteria multiply and increase the risk of infection in those who consume the food
lines.name: English

lines.value: some foods commonly associated with illness include raw or undercooked meat poultry seafood and eggs raw sprouts unpasteurized milk and soft cheeses and fruit and vegetable juices
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the developing world especially sub saharan africa and asia cholera is a common cause of gastroenteritis.<
lines.name: English

lines.value: > this infection is usually transmitted by contaminated water or food
lines.name: English

lines.value: toxigenic clostridium difficile is an important cause of diarrhea that occurs more often in the elderly
lines.name: English

lines.value: infants can carry these bacteria without developing symptoms
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is a common cause of diarrhea in those who are hospitalized and is frequently associated with antibiotic use
lines.name: English

lines.value: staphylococcus aureus infectious diarrhea may also occur in those who have used antibiotics
lines.name: English

lines.value: acute traveler's diarrhea is usually a type of bacterial gastroenteritis while the persistent form is usually parasitic
lines.name: English

lines.value: acid suppressing medication appears to increase the risk of significant infection after exposure to a number of organisms including clostridium difficile salmonella and campylobacter species
lines.name: English

lines.value: the risk is greater in those taking proton pump inhibitors than with h2 antagonists
lines.name: English

lines.value: a number of protozoa can cause gastroenteritis - most commonly giardia lamblia - but entamoeba histolytica cryptosporidium spp and other species have also been implicated
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a group these agents comprise about 10% of cases in children
lines.name: English

lines.value: giardia occurs more commonly in the developing world but this etiologic agent causes this type of illness to some degree nearly everywhere
lines.name: English

lines.value: it occurs more commonly in persons who have traveled to areas with high prevalence children who attend day care men who have sex with men and following disasters
lines.name: English

lines.value: transmission may occur via consumption of contaminated water or when people share personal objects
lines.name: English

lines.value: in places with wet and dry seasons water quality typically worsens during the wet season and this correlates with the time of outbreaks
lines.name: English

lines.value: in areas of the world with four seasons infections are more common in the winter
lines.name: English

lines.value: bottle feeding of babies with improperly sanitized bottles is a significant cause on a global scale
lines.name: English

lines.value: transmission rates are also related to poor hygiene especially among children in crowded households and in those with pre existing poor nutritional status
lines.name: English

lines.value: after developing tolerance adults may carry certain organisms without exhibiting signs or symptoms and thus act as natural reservoirs of contagion
lines.name: English

lines.value: while some agents such as shigella only occur in primates others may occur in a wide variety of animals such as giardia
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are a number of non infectious causes of inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of the more common include medications like nsaids certain foods such as lactose in those who are intolerant and gluten in those with celiac disease
lines.name: English

lines.value: crohn's disease is also a non infectious source of often severe gastroenteritis
lines.name: English

lines.value: disease secondary to toxins may also occur
lines.name: English

lines.value: some food related conditions associated with nausea vomiting and diarrhea include ciguatera poisoning due to consumption of contaminated predatory fish scombroid associated with the consumption of certain types of spoiled fish tetrodotoxin poisoning from the consumption of puffer fish among others and botulism typically due to improperly preserved food
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the united states rates of emergency department use for noninfectious gastroenteritis dropped 30% from 2006 until 2011
lines.name: English

lines.value: of the twenty most common conditions seen in the emergency department rates of noninfectious gastroenteritis had the largest decrease in visits in that time period
lines.name: English

lines.value: gastroenteritis is defined as vomiting or diarrhea due to inflammation of the small or large bowel often due to infection
lines.name: English

lines.value: the changes in the small bowel are typically noninflammatory while the ones in the large bowel are inflammatory
lines.name: English

lines.value: the number of pathogens required to cause an infection varies from as few as one for cryptosporidium to as many as 10 8 for vibrio cholerae
lines.name: English

lines.value: gastroenteritis is typically diagnosed clinically based on a person's signs and symptoms
lines.name: English

lines.value: determining the exact cause is usually not needed as it does not alter management of the condition
lines.name: English

lines.value: however stool cultures should be performed in those with blood in the stool those who might have been exposed to food poisoning and those who have recently traveled to the developing world
lines.name: English

lines.value: it may also be appropriate in children young than 5 old people and those with poor immune function
lines.name: English

lines.value: diagnostic testing may also be done for surveillance
lines.name: English

lines.value: as hypoglycemia occurs in approximately 10% of infants and young children measuring serum glucose in this population is recommended
lines.name: English

lines.value: electrolytes and kidney function should also be checked when there is a concern about severe dehydration
lines.name: English

lines.value: a determination of whether or not the person has dehydration is an important part of the assessment with dehydration typically divided into mild 3-5% moderate 6-9% and severe ≥10% cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: in children the most accurate signs of moderate or severe dehydration are a prolonged capillary refill poor skin turgor and abnormal breathing
lines.name: English

lines.value: other useful findings when used in combination include sunken eyes decreased activity a lack of tears and a dry mouth
lines.name: English

lines.value: a normal urinary output and oral fluid intake is reassuring
lines.name: English

lines.value: laboratory testing is of little clinical benefit in determining the degree of dehydration
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus the use of urine testing or ultrasounds is generally not needed
lines.name: English

lines.value: other potential causes of signs and symptoms that mimic those seen in gastroenteritis that need to be ruled out include appendicitis volvulus inflammatory bowel disease urinary tract infections and diabetes mellitus
lines.name: English

lines.value: pancreatic insufficiency short bowel syndrome whipple's disease coeliac disease and laxative abuse should also be considered
lines.name: English

lines.value: the differential diagnosis can be complicated somewhat if the person exhibits only vomiting or diarrhea rather than both
lines.name: English

lines.value: appendicitis may present with vomiting abdominal pain and a small amount of diarrhea in up to 33% of cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is in contrast to the large amount of diarrhea that is typical of gastroenteritis
lines.name: English

lines.value: infections of the lungs or urinary tract in children may also cause vomiting or diarrhea
lines.name: English

lines.value: classical diabetic ketoacidosis dka presents with abdominal pain nausea and vomiting but without diarrhea
lines.name: English

lines.value: one study found that 17% of children with dka were initially diagnosed as having gastroenteritis
lines.name: English

lines.value: a supply of easily accessible uncontaminated water and good sanitation practices are important for reducing rates of infection and clinically significant gastroenteritis
lines.name: English

lines.value: personal measures such as hand washing with soap have been found to decrease rates of gastroenteritis in both the developing and developed world by as much as 30%
lines.name: English

lines.value: alcohol based gels may also be effective
lines.name: English

lines.value: food or drink that is thought to be contaminated should be avoided
lines.name: English

lines.value: breastfeeding is important especially in places with poor hygiene as is improvement of hygiene generally
lines.name: English

lines.value: breast milk reduces both the frequency of infections and their duration
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to both its effectiveness and safety in 2009 the world health organization recommended that the rotavirus vaccine be offered to all children globally
lines.name: English

lines.value: two commercial rotavirus vaccines exist and several more are in development
lines.name: English

lines.value: in africa and asia these vaccines reduced severe disease among infants and countries that have put in place national immunization programs have seen a decline in the rates and severity of disease
lines.name: English

lines.value: this vaccine may also prevent illness in non vaccinated children by reducing the number of circulating infections
lines.name: English

lines.value: since 2000 the implementation of a rotavirus vaccination program in the united states has substantially decreased the number of cases of diarrhea by as much as 80 percent
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first dose of vaccine should be given to infants between 6 and 15 weeks of age
lines.name: English

lines.value: the oral cholera vaccine has been found to be 50 60% effective over 2 years
lines.name: English

lines.value: gastroenteritis is usually an acute and self limiting disease that does not require medication
lines.name: English

lines.value: the preferred treatment in those with mild to moderate dehydration is oral rehydration therapy ort
lines.name: English

lines.value: for children at risk of dehydration from vomiting taking a single dose of the anti vomiting medication metoclopramide or ondansetron may be helpful and butylscopolamine is useful in treating abdominal pain
lines.name: English

lines.value: the primary treatment of gastroenteritis in both children and adults is rehydration
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is preferably achieved by drinking rehydration solution although intravenous delivery may be required if there is a decreased level of consciousness or if dehydration is severe
lines.name: English

lines.value: drinking replacement therapy products made with complex carbohydrates i.e those made from wheat or rice may be superior to those based on simple sugars
lines.name: English

lines.value: drinks especially high in simple sugars such as soft drinks and fruit juices are not recommended in children under 5 years of age as they may increase diarrhea
lines.name: English

lines.value: plain water may be used if more specific ort preparations are unavailable or the person is not willing to drink them
lines.name: English

lines.value: a nasogastric tube can be used in young children to administer fluids if warranted
lines.name: English

lines.value: in those who require intravenous fluids one to four hours worth is often sufficient
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is recommended that breast fed infants continue to be nursed in the usual fashion and that formula fed infants continue their formula immediately after rehydration with ort
lines.name: English

lines.value: lactose free or lactose reduced formulas usually are not necessary
lines.name: English

lines.value: children should continue their usual diet during episodes of diarrhea with the exception that foods high in simple sugars should be avoided
lines.name: English

lines.value: the brat diet bananas rice applesauce toast and tea is no longer recommended as it contains insufficient nutrients and has no benefit over normal feeding
lines.name: English

lines.value: some probiotics have been shown to be beneficial in reducing both the duration of illness and the frequency of stools
lines.name: English

lines.value: they may also be useful in preventing and treating antibiotic associated diarrhea
lines.name: English

lines.value: fermented milk products such as yogurt are similarly beneficial
lines.name: English

lines.value: zinc supplementation appears to be effective in both treating and preventing diarrhea among children in the developing world
lines.name: English

lines.value: antiemetic medications may be helpful for treating vomiting in children
lines.name: English

lines.value: ondansetron has some utility with a single dose being associated with less need for intravenous fluids fewer hospitalizations and decreased vomiting
lines.name: English

lines.value: metoclopramide might also be helpful
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the use of ondansetron might possibly be linked to an increased rate of return to hospital in children
lines.name: English

lines.value: the intravenous preparation of ondansetron may be given orally if clinical judgment warrants
lines.name: English

lines.value: dimenhydrinate while reducing vomiting does not appear to have a significant clinical benefit
lines.name: English

lines.value: antibiotics are not usually used for gastroenteritis although they are sometimes recommended if symptoms are particularly severe or if a susceptible bacterial cause is isolated or suspected
lines.name: English

lines.value: if antibiotics are to be employed a macrolide such as azithromycin is preferred over a fluoroquinolone due to higher rates of resistance to the latter
lines.name: English

lines.value: pseudomembranous colitis usually caused by antibiotic use is managed by discontinuing the causative agent and treating it with either metronidazole or vancomycin
lines.name: English

lines.value: bacteria and protozoans that are amenable to treatment include shigella salmonella typhi and giardia species
lines.name: English

lines.value: in those with giardia species or entamoeba histolytica tinidazole treatment is recommended and superior to metronidazole
lines.name: English

lines.value: the world health organization who recommends the use of antibiotics in young children who have both bloody diarrhea and fever
lines.name: English

lines.value: antimotility medication has a theoretical risk of causing complications and although clinical experience has shown this to be unlikely these drugs are discouraged in people with bloody diarrhea or diarrhea that is complicated by fever
lines.name: English

lines.value: loperamide an opioid analogue is commonly used for the symptomatic treatment of diarrhea
lines.name: English

lines.value: loperamide is not recommended in children however as it may cross the immature blood brain barrier and cause toxicity
lines.name: English

lines.value: bismuth subsalicylate an insoluble complex of trivalent bismuth and salicylate can be used in mild to moderate cases but salicylate toxicity is theoretically possible
lines.name: English

lines.value: diarrhoeal diseases world map daly who2004.svg
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1980 gastroenteritis from all causes caused 4.6 million deaths in children with the majority occurring in the developing world
lines.name: English

lines.value: death rates were reduced significantly to approximately 1.5 million deaths annually by the year 2000 largely due to the introduction and widespread use of oral rehydration therapy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the us infections causing gastroenteritis are the second most common infection after the common cold and they result in between 200 and 375 million cases of acute diarrhea and approximately ten thousand deaths annually with 150 to 300 of these deaths in children less than five years of age
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first usage of gastroenteritis was in 1825
lines.name: English

lines.value: before this time it was commonly known as typhoid fever or cholera morbus among others or less specifically as griping of the guts surfeit flux colic bowel complaint or any one of a number of other archaic names for acute diarrhea
lines.name: English

lines.value: cholera morbus is a historical term that was used to refer to gastroenteritis rather than specifically cholera
lines.name: English

lines.value: gastroenteritis is associated with many colloquial names including montezuma's revenge delhi belly la turista and back door sprint among others
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has played a role in many military campaigns and is believed to be the origin of the term no guts no glory
lines.name: English

lines.value: gastroenteritis is the main reason for 3.7 million visits to physicians a year in the united states and 3 million visits in france
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the united states gastroenteritis as a whole is believed to result in costs of 23 billion usd per year with that due to rotavirus alone resulting in estimated costs of 1 billion usd a year
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are a number of vaccines against gastroenteritis in development
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example vaccines against shigella and enterotoxigenic escherichia coli etec two of the leading bacterial causes of gastroenteritis worldwide
lines.name: English

lines.value: many of the same agents cause gastroenteritis in cats and dogs as in humans
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most common organisms are campylobacter clostridium difficile clostridium perfringens and salmonella
lines.name: English

lines.value: a large number of toxic plants may also cause symptoms
lines.name: English

lines.value: some agents are more specific to a certain species
lines.name: English

lines.value: transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus tgev occurs in pigs resulting in vomiting diarrhea and dehydration
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is believed to be introduced to pigs by wild birds and there is no specific treatment available
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is not transmissible to humans
lines.name: English

lines.value: ;notes
lines.name: English
